mould.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a hollow container that you pour a liquid or soft substance into, so that when it becomes solid, it takes the shape of the container
mould.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Another method, used especially for figures, was to pour the clay into a mould.
mould.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if someone is in a particular mould, or fits into a particular mould, they have all the attitudes and qualities typical of a type of person
mould.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: She didn’t quite fit into the standard ‘high-flying businesswoman’ mould.
a socialist intellectual in the mould of Anthony Crosland
in the same mould (as somebody/something)/in the mould of somebody/something
mould.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a soft green, grey, or black substance that grows on food which has been kept too long, and on objects that are in warm wet air
mould.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The chemical was used to kill a mold that grows on peanuts.
The walls were black with mould.
mould.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meanings 2 & 3
mould.translation[0].note_box[0].section: The program broke the mould of the traditional TV chat show.
She doesn't fit the mould of the stereotypical mother.
be in the mould of somebody/something
As an actor he is in the mould of Bruce Lee.
He didn't want to be cast in the mould of being an academic.
come from a different/the same mould
He clearly comes from a different mould than his brother.
He was not a conservative in the traditional mould.
mould.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to shape a soft substance by pressing or rolling it or by putting it into a mould
mould.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Mould the sausage meat into little balls.
mould.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to influence the way someone’s character or attitudes develop
mould.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: an attempt to mold public opinion
I try to take young athletes and mold them into team players.
mould.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to fit closely to the shape of something, or to make something fit closely
mould.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: The lining of the boot molds itself to the shape of your foot.
Her wet dress was moulded to her body.
